bean classcast exception no finally history, yiehaa... thanks to the improved classloader and thanks also to the more complicated bean reloading strategies. renderer reloading strategy improved as well, since the renderer is a flyweight pattern we do not have to copy anything, we just drop everything and reload anew.

bean reloading now without classcast exceptions, finally...

- Removed unused folders. - Created a package that will contain the module after some code cleanup.

- Added a new compiler API that only knows how to compile one file at a time. Note that it's still possible to compile mutiple files by just using multiple method calls, but some of my parts will require that much control.
- Added some custom class loaders and testcases. - Corrected the POM, it didn't include the JUnit dependency.
- Added a class loader that knows how to load class files from the file system.

upgrade to the latest extval version, bean resolution on el level did not work out we cannot coerce the type properly without instantiating the bean, hence we have to live with the class level only.

https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/EXTSCRIPT-143 fixup for the compiler interface we now have a dedicated single compile, we also moved the compile part now to the servlet filter so that we have the compile itself outside of jsf, that way we can ensure that a new version of the class is present when jsf kicks in (important for resource handlers etc...)

https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/EXTSCRIPT-143 replacing the standard tainted mechanism on classloader level with a real touch mechanism on filesystem level, the advantage is we on classloader level can rely entirely on the class file has changed mechanism for reloading, which means a slightly better decoupling between classloader and resource monitor, theoretically a compile on the fly already should work, but we wont enable that before 1.1.

https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/EXTSCRIPT-143 reverted the compiled check because the java compiler automatically compiles dependencies with it which might not have changed, and we are getting classcast exceptions, it is better simply to check for refresh requested instead for now .. but in the end it might be preferrable to check in the refresh part for tainted (backwards referencing) and compiled (forward referencing)

https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/EXTSCRIPT-144 crossported the parts of our resource handling which affects my code to decouple this part from the shared impl. It probably will be entirely replaced by a leaner less complex implementation post 1.0, but for now this has to suffice.
